text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
iggy and the stooges record ready to die
iggy and the stooges detroit based band
iggy pop front man one of rock music's
original badasses the band has three
seminal records under their belts they
are bloody they're dirty they're filthy
they're
the band lived fast and their very
abrupt breakup in the mid 70s reflected
that because for their time there was
very little about their brand of rock
music that felt
civilized and i would say that this
energy that the band would put into
their music really paid off in some
long-term dividends because just the
guts that they laid out in their records
like raw power and funhouse have
withstood the test of time and feel just
as high octane today as i'm sure they
did back then after the demise of the
ban there were some post stooges musical
projects to take note of that were
pretty great like ron ashton's destroy
all monsters and iggy pop as well had a
pretty successful solo career with a
handful of great records he mellowed out
a little bit musically but not in a bad
way he put out some interesting
post punk stuff some art rock stuff he
got a little more adventurous past his
stooges material and put out quite a few
records in the 80s and 90s but the 2000s
saw these stooges actually reforming for
live performances with mike watt from
the minutemen playing bass and this
performing in the band's popularity just
kind of getting going again led to the
result of a new
studio album the band's first studio
album in decades the weirdness in 2007
steve albini produced it and in my
opinion this record easily one of the
most tragic
studio recording
comebacks a band has ever made i mean
literally so tragic that the band and
its label literally omitted the
existence of this album out from the
press release for this new lp saying
that this album is like a direct release
after raw power really
the raw power on the weirdness was gone
the band's intensity was just replaced
with very terrible lyrics my idea of fun
is killing everyone and these lyrics
were delivered with vocals that really
really lacked ferocity and the guitars
really kind of lacked ferocity too just
didn't have the guts that they used to
back in the day to me there was just a
certain tameness to their new sound on
this record the stooges were sounding
like the groomed and commodified version
of what wild rock music is sold as today
as opposed to what it was when the
stooges were
now with this latest record ready to die
which unfortunately comes after the
passing of ron ashton we have round two
essentially of this comeback
and i have to say admittedly the stooges
are sounding a little gutsier than they
did on their previous full length they
aren't completely missing the mark the
band still has the very garagey sound
songs like dirty deal have a very fast
energetic riff pretty solid solo as well
but that desperation that just being
pushed to the edge
feel of the stooges music is just still
not
on
this record it's still not on this
recording i mean i i can't express i
can't put it into words just that that
feeling of like
my life depends on this music
existing
that
vibe is not on here for sure this record
is not really an insult to their legacy
in the way that the weirdness was but
essentially you're just getting a lot of
wild garage rock tracks here that do not
feel
that wild and a few of them especially
tracks like beat that guy that
experiment with strings and background
vocals venture into territory that has
never really been the stooges strong
point so i'm just wondering why they're
even going down this road to begin with
there are some tracks on here that have
lyrics that make me cry
and cringe like the song job i got a job
and it don't pay there are just
some moments where iggy pop's words just
are too obnoxious
for words to be completely honest and
his voice it's it's like him and the
band are really worried about how it
sounds at all whether or not it's just
underwhelming during a point that is i
guess shooting for something high energy
or just warbling really awkwardly or
just off pitch on some of the moments
where it seems like the band is pulling
together something a little more ballad
like i do think the guitars overall on
this album are better they're more
ferocious it's more gnash teeth it's
just showing those canines and as far as
guitars and drums locking together and
making a groove just making a tough ass
vibe songs like dd's dirty deal or ready
to die these songs really have their
stuff together and the song gun too is
pretty good as far as guitars and drums
go but there's so many tracks on this
album i feel like would have gone over
so much better if iggy's vocals weren't
so just
uh flat overall i did think this album
was a step up from the weirdness however
that doesn't necessarily mean that i
enjoyed it though there were some bright
spots coming out of the guitars and the
drums together
i
didn't really care for the vocals i'm
not a single song there were some tracks
that i didn't really care for the mix
either where it felt like the guitars
were turned up so high i couldn't really
appreciate much of anything else in the
mix and like i mentioned toward the
beginning of this review there were
songs on here where it seemed like iggy
and the stooges were experimenting with
some softer ideas that i just don't
really think went over all that well i'm
really feeling
a light to decent for on this thing if
you've given it a listen what did you
think of it did you love it did you hate
it why
what do you think i should review next
and that's it
anthony fantano
iggy and the stooges
forever
